The _Clusterize_ command operates on clustering data (like that produced by MUTIC and MOBRA transformations), grouping features in that data accordingly to their similarity. Currently, the only clustering algorithm effectively implemented is Omniclust, and therefore there is no parametrization yet for clustering method to be used. The present syntax of this command is:

{{{
java task.Clusterize <-d clustering dataset> <-o output file> [-b base categorial dataset] [-datasetClusteringMetric similarity metric]
}}}

_similarity metric_ can assume the values _Euclidean_ and _Cosine_, the only similarity metrics implemented so far. (If this option is not specified, the default value _Euclidean_ defined in _pipeline.properties_ is assumed.) _base categorial dataset_ specifies the original dataset used to generate the clustering dataset, either directly through horizontal or vertical transformations or indirectly through MOBRA. (This is a clumsy requirement for getting feature descriptions, and it will soon be eliminated by a refactoring of the clustering dataset generation by the !ClusteringTransformer command.) And here is an utilization example of the command:

{{{
openbiomind/classes $ java task.Clusterize -d datafiles/mobra.126.tab -o outputs/mobra.126.txt -b datafiles/varm126.tab -datasetClusteringMetric Cosine

}}}

As one can see, clustering output is presented in decreasing order of "geometric quality". (The product homogeneity times separation, which are geometric measurements of how compacted is a cluster and how far from neighbors it is.) Also, so far clustering is not hierarchical, for all clustering analysis currently performed as part of the research work at Biomind are concerned only with the first level of clusters. (The one shown in the output above.)
